item.title: @395437265 on 2024-06-20 18:46:44+00:00 (#6905)
item.description: yes, understood

item.title: @HughEverett on 2024-06-20 18:46:23+00:00 (#6904)
item.description: It just doesn't show you once it's not within the range but not showing you doesn't mean it didn't happen.

item.title: @395437265 on 2024-06-20 18:45:26+00:00 (#6903)
item.description: i see..

item.title: @HughEverett on 2024-06-20 18:45:16+00:00 (#6902)
item.description: Once you try to hook 001995a4, HyperDbg will automatically hook the entire page boundary (00199000 to 00199fff) for you.

item.title: @HughEverett on 2024-06-20 18:44:10+00:00 (#6901)
item.description: It does not make that much difference.

item.title: @395437265 on 2024-06-20 18:43:42+00:00 (#6900)
item.description: or will it fail ?

item.title: @395437265 on 2024-06-20 18:43:34+00:00 (#6899)
item.description: will try to add if condition now

item.title: @HughEverett on 2024-06-20 18:43:33+00:00 (#6898)
item.description: The rate of access is too high

item.title: @HughEverett on 2024-06-20 18:43:24+00:00 (#6897)
item.description: Ah, so that's the reason

item.title: @395437265 on 2024-06-20 18:42:36+00:00 (#6896)
@HughEverett on 2024-06-20 18:40:07+00:00 (#6895)
item.description: Or from 199000 to 199fff

item.title: @HughEverett on 2024-06-20 18:39:39+00:00 (#6894)
item.description:
No, the page boundary start from PAGE_ALIGN(001995A4) which means you need sth like:
00199000 l fff

item.title: @395437265 on 2024-06-20 18:38:27+00:00 (#6893)
item.description: i need to montor 001995A4+4kb ?

item.title: @395437265 on 2024-06-20 18:37:10+00:00 (#6892)
item.description: what i need to do to achieve it ?

item.title: @HughEverett on 2024-06-20 18:35:13+00:00 (#6891)
item.description:
And also not sure if you already knew it or not but the $context pseudo-register shows you the address of the memory accessed by the instruction that triggered the hook.
https://docs.hyperdbg.org/commands/extension-commands/monitor#context

item.title: @HughEverett on 2024-06-20 18:32:25+00:00 (#6890)
item.description: Yes. Get a printf from it

item.title: @395437265 on 2024-06-20 18:32:11+00:00 (#6889)
item.description: all 4kb ?

item.title: @HughEverett on 2024-06-20 18:32:01+00:00 (#6888)
item.description: Can you check the entire page boundary?

item.title: @395437265 on 2024-06-20 18:31:42+00:00 (#6887)
item.description: i also wonder :D

item.title: @HughEverett on 2024-06-20 18:31:32+00:00 (#6886)
item.description: Why? ü§î

item.title: @HughEverett on 2024-06-20 18:30:58+00:00 (#6885)
item.description: So, each access to this 4kb cause a VM-exit, but HyperDbg filters it and only show you the accesses on your target address range.

item.title: @395437265 on 2024-06-20 18:30:47+00:00 (#6884)
@HughEverett on 2024-06-20 18:30:00+00:00 (#6883)
item.description: So, that's the reason. HyperDbg puts hook on entire 4 kb granularity of the page boundary. Not just 4 bytes. Because it's how EPT works.

item.title: @395437265 on 2024-06-20 18:28:27+00:00 (#6882)
item.description: i think so.. there is buffer prepared for network sending

item.title: @HughEverett on 2024-06-20 18:27:49+00:00 (#6881)
item.description: Is it (the entire 4kb of the target page) located on a page with high rate of memory access?

item.title: @395437265 on 2024-06-20 18:22:19+00:00 (#6880)
@HughEverett on 2024-06-20 16:35:26+00:00 (#6879)
item.description: In the Debugger Mode, traps/bps are intercepted.

item.title: @HughEverett on 2024-06-20 16:35:02+00:00 (#6878)
item.description: In VMI mode, traps/breakpoints are not intercepted by default.

item.title: @HughEverett on 2024-06-20 16:34:30+00:00 (#6877)
item.description: No, it's the case for HyperDbg. Windows (OS) doesn't have any details about the presence of a top-level (ring -1) debugger.

item.title: @instw0 on 2024-06-20 16:32:44+00:00 (#6876)
item.description: and trap and breakpoint are not disabled in the hypervisor.... does windows think that the debugger is connected?

item.title: @HughEverett on 2024-06-20 16:31:31+00:00 (#6875)
item.description: And also post your function here if it's possible. I'm gonna check it too.

item.title: @HughEverett on 2024-06-20 16:31:09+00:00 (#6874)
item.description: It's easier to modify a user-mode application and introspect it's behavior. Try to make a similar check function check in user-mode.

item.title: @HughEverett on 2024-06-20 16:29:50+00:00 (#6873)
item.description: I think you need to create a user-mode application with the same technique.

item.title: @instw0 on 2024-06-20 16:29:47+00:00 (#6872)
item.description: driver obfuckate vmprotect

item.title: @instw0 on 2024-06-20 16:29:28+00:00 (#6871)
item.description: yes

item.title: @HughEverett on 2024-06-20 16:29:21+00:00 (#6870)
item.description: Are you analyzing a driver?

item.title: @instw0 on 2024-06-20 16:28:51+00:00 (#6869)
item.description: kernel

item.title: @HughEverett on 2024-06-20 16:28:44+00:00 (#6868)
item.description: User-mode try/catch?

item.title: @HughEverett on 2024-06-20 16:28:13+00:00 (#6867)
item.description: Depends on how CPU behaves in this case. If it triggers immediately then you need to inject a #DB.

item.title: @HughEverett on 2024-06-20 16:26:58+00:00 (#6866)
item.description:
Still don't understand what you're trying to do but if you want to trigger an exception in your target user-mode app, you need to inject an event in HyperDbg by using these functions:
https://docs.hyperdbg.org/commands/scripting-language/functions/events/event_inject
And:
https://docs.hyperdbg.org/commands/scripting-language/functions/events/event_inject_error_code
These are the functions that deliver exception to the guest debuggee application. The assembly code you used in your event will cause division by zero in HyperDbg's VMM which is simply handled in VMX root-mode and it's ignored by HyperDbg's division by zero exception handler.

item.title: @HughEverett on 2024-06-20 16:22:37+00:00 (#6865)
item.description: Larry you can follow this discussion, it's probably the problem with verifying packets.

item.title: @instw0 on 2024-06-20 16:21:39+00:00 (#6863)
item.description: just processing rflags.tf should take place inside the try catch block, not in the debugger

item.title: @instw0 on 2024-06-20 16:19:22+00:00 (#6862)
item.description: that is, the exception should be triggered immediately after the cpuid instruction?

item.title: @HughEverett on 2024-06-20 16:19:04+00:00 (#6861)
item.description: Ah, unfortunately this feature is not working as expected. We previously had a discussion in this group and conclude that this feature is not working. You need to use a virtual serial device.

item.title: @instw0 on 2024-06-20 16:18:42+00:00 (#6860)
item.description: Are we processing the trap inside now?

item.title: @HughEverett on 2024-06-20 16:17:04+00:00 (#6858)
item.description: Yes, but it depends on when CPU gives us this #Db, the reason such a technique exists is because CPUID has precedence over #Db's exception bitmap vm-exit.

item.title: @instw0 on 2024-06-20 16:16:34+00:00 (#6857)
item.description: I'm trying

item.title: @HughEverett on 2024-06-20 16:15:41+00:00 (#6856)
item.description: If I were in your shoes, I tried to make a simple application with your target technique (popfq TF), and I try to trigger the behavior in HyperDbg like showing a message using (LogInfo) without modifying anything. Once I was sure that this technique can be correctly detected (by seeing the message), then I try to modify the guest state. I think this is the best approach to handle this VMProtect technique.

item.title: @instw0 on 2024-06-20 16:13:05+00:00 (#6855)
item.description: and is it being processed?

item.title: @HughEverett on 2024-06-20 16:12:11+00:00 (#6854)
item.description: Yes a trap flag generates a #Db.

item.title: @395437265 on 2024-06-20 15:44:38+00:00 (#6853)
item.description: im trying to stop app in particular state by modifying code to raise division exception, now app stops with unhandled exception and windows popup appears. i can take dump, state is intact, however, in traces i can see windows exception handler mechanism, so real trace is not accessible. actually i wanted to cause BSOD, but it seems its not so easy for usermode

item.title: @6306026391 on 2024-06-20 15:18:33+00:00 (#6852)
item.description:
I'm trying to do remote debugging with 2 physical machines over COM but the connection never seems to complete, the debugger stays on
HyperDbg> .debug remote serial 115200 com1 Waiting for debuggee to connect...
And the debugee:
HyperDbg> .debug prepare serial 115200 com3 current processor vendor is : GenuineIntel virtualization technology is vt-x vmx operation is supported by your processor
I've tested the COM connection with PuTTY and all appears to be working fine there, any suggestions on what I can do to debug/fix the issue?

item.title: @instw0 on 2024-06-20 15:03:55+00:00 (#6851)
item.description: EventinjectDebugBreakpoint is tf processing?

item.title: @instw0 on 2024-06-20 15:02:00+00:00 (#6849)
item.description: debugger is frozen

item.title: @HughEverett on 2024-06-20 15:01:24+00:00 (#6848)
item.description: Just added a check? Any modification to the TF Flag?

item.title: @HughEverett on 2024-06-20 15:00:35+00:00 (#6847)
item.description: Yes

item.title: @HughEverett on 2024-06-20 15:00:11+00:00 (#6846)
item.description: Not sure what you trying to do? The division by zero error you're trying produce is handled in VMX root-mode because all of the events (except !epthook2, not !epthook) execute assembly in VMX root-mode, so it's not handled by guest (Windows) IDT and it's passed to HyperDbg's HOST IDT exception handler.

item.title: @HughEverett on 2024-06-20 14:56:03+00:00 (#6845)
item.description: Ah, this one is also mentioned by another person in issues. This one should be updated in the phnt repo that we used it as a submodule. We could also update HyperDbg's fork and comment it. I'll fix it.

item.title: @HughEverett on 2024-06-19 15:34:48+00:00 (#6833)
item.description:
VMCALL is unconditional, !dr needs configuration. Pls check this file as it's the file responsible for configuring events:
https://github.com/HyperDbg/HyperDbg/blob/master/hyperdbg/hprdbgkd/code/debugger/events/ApplyEvents.c

item.title: @instw0 on 2024-06-19 12:47:42+00:00 (#6832)
item.description: accordingly !vmcall, !dr... they also cause the exit from the virtual machine (vmexit)

item.title: @HughEverett on 2024-06-19 11:43:59+00:00 (#6831)
item.description: Basically, hwdbg registers are like @hw_pin0, @hw_pin1, @hw_pin2, ..., @hw_pinX and @hw_port0, @hw_port1, @hw_port2, ..., @hw_portX. We need to find the best way of adding these registers (and new pseudo-registers) to the parser.

item.title: @HughEverett on 2024-06-19 11:40:26+00:00 (#6830)
item.description: @xmaple555 we need to think of the best way to parse scripts of the hwdbg debugger. The registers and pseudo-registers of the hwdbg is different from x64 registers. ü§î

item.title: @HughEverett on 2024-06-19 11:33:34+00:00 (#6828)
item.description:
Development progress update: hwdbg has reached the point where it can run HyperDbg scripts (dslang) for chip/FPGA debugging. Still under development!
https://github.com/HyperDbg/HyperDbg/tree/dev/hwdbg

item.title: @HughEverett on 2024-06-19 11:27:39+00:00 (#6826)
item.description: Conditions checks for each extension command is basically software-side implemented. RDTSC/RDTSCP cause conditional VM-exits (not remember, either on primary or secondary proc-based VMCS controls).

item.title: @archercreat on 2024-06-19 08:14:41+00:00 (#6825)
item.description: Ah yes, my bad. It actually cares üòÄ https://github.com/jmpoep/vmprotect-3.5.1/blob/d8fcb7c0ffd4fb45a8cfbd770c8b117d7dbe52b5/runtime/core.cc#L306

item.title: @instw0 on 2024-06-19 08:09:03+00:00 (#6824)
item.description: RDTSC?

item.title: @archercreat on 2024-06-19 07:56:52+00:00 (#6823)
item.description: Not related to hyperdbg, but vmprotect does not care if you break at cpuid or at the nop. https://github.com/jmpoep/vmprotect-3.5.1/blob/d8fcb7c0ffd4fb45a8cfbd770c8b117d7dbe52b5/runtime/core.cc#L771

item.title: @instw0 on 2024-06-19 07:36:56+00:00 (#6822)
item.description: it's just that cpuid causes an unconditional vmexit anyway, and in the case of !rdtsc?

item.title: @instw0 on 2024-06-19 07:34:27+00:00 (#6821)
item.description: yes, I've read it, I just wanted to clarify that the debugger is at the event !cpuid, !rdtsc set conditions in the vmxsc structure? then vmm receives a notification(or vmexit)?

item.title: @HughEverett on 2024-06-19 06:09:16+00:00 (#6820)
item.description: You need to provide more details. What is the generation of your processor? which version of Windows? and how to reproduce it?

item.title: @zhang_derek on 2024-06-19 05:57:16+00:00 (#6819)
item.description: How to fix

item.title: @zhang_derek on 2024-06-19 05:56:57+00:00 (#6818)
item.description: win10 bluescreenÔºå

item.title: @HughEverett on 2024-06-19 04:43:13+00:00 (#6817)
item.description:
RDTSC is configured from VMCS, VMCALL is unconditional VM-exit and !msrread !msrwrite use MSR Bitmaps. Take a look at Hypervisor From Scratch, I think it gives you an idea how HyperDbg works internally:
https://rayanfam.com/tutorials/

item.title: @instw0 on 2024-06-19 04:36:17+00:00 (#6816)
item.description: read msr in vmxcs?

item.title: @instw0 on 2024-06-19 04:35:33+00:00 (#6815)
item.description: how do you keep track of instructions that don't cause the VM to exit? example RDTCS, vmcall...

item.title: @HughEverett on 2024-06-19 04:32:31+00:00 (#6814)
item.description: We process it as VM-exit, not interrupt.

item.title: @HughEverett on 2024-06-19 04:32:15+00:00 (#6813)
item.description: For !tsc Yes, for !cpuid No. CPUID is unconditional VM-exit. Here is a list of instructions with unconditional VM-exit.

item.title: @instw0 on 2024-06-18 13:32:00+00:00 (#6812)
item.description: then we process it in vmm as a debugger interrupt?

item.title: @instw0 on 2024-06-18 13:30:09+00:00 (#6811)
item.description: when we use events !cpuid, !rdtsc do we configure the vmxcs structure to vm-exit when an event occurs?

item.title: @HughEverett on 2024-06-18 12:57:08+00:00 (#6810)
item.description: Not sure if I correctly understand what you mean. ü§î What is event(!cpu)?

item.title: @HughEverett on 2024-06-18 12:56:06+00:00 (#6809)
item.description: NMI is not realted to step-in or step-over, HyperDbg just uses NMI to halt (pause) all cores in the Debugger Mode.

item.title: @HughEverett on 2024-06-18 12:54:33+00:00 (#6808)
item.description: Only the 'i' command (instrumentation step-in) uses MTF (Monitor Trap Flag). Other stepping command like 't' is implemented same as WinDbg by using RFLAGS's TF.
